item.title: Multi-objective Learning and Fairness in AI
item.description:
In modern Machine Learning, maximizing accuracy is rarely the only goal. Models must often balance competing requirements such as fairness, interpretability, and robustness. Traditional approaches that combine these metrics into a single loss function often fail to capture the complex landscape of the trade-offs involved.

This project investigates Multi-objective Learning (MOL): the direct integration of optimization solvers into the neural network training loop. By treating learning as a multi-objective problem, we empower data scientists to explore the Pareto front of possible models before making a final decision.

Research Focus:

  • Algorithmic Fairness: A primary application of this research is in Credit Scoring, where we aim to maximize profit/accuracy while minimizing discrimination across demographic groups (e.g., race or gender).
  • Multi-task Learning: Simultaneously training a single neural network to perform multiple tasks (e.g., risk prediction and churn prediction) without one task dominating the gradient updates.
  • Hyperparameter Tuning: Utilizing bilevel optimization techniques to automatically adjust regularization terms and model architecture during training.
  • Software Framework: Development of machinemoo, a high-level library that simplifies the modeling of these complex trade-offs, making multi-objective training accessible to the ML community.
